Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Reconstructing the contemporary history and progenitor of SARS-CoV-2 strains causing COVID-19
Award.AbstractNarration: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is the root cause of the COVID-19 disease that has caused many deaths in the US and millions of infections worldwide. It is expected to infect many more and is feared to inflict a higher death toll, requiring immediate research efforts to understand its genome biology and evolution. Experimental laboratories have quickly assembled tens of thousands of CoV-2 genomes to characterize its variation and to track the spread of COVID-19. Now a meaningful analysis of this enormous dataset is needed to understand patterns of coronavirus change over the last few months. These evolutionary patterns are the key to making predictions and developing products to fight COVID-19. The discovery of evolutionary patterns requires new methods explicitly designed to exploit salient features of coronavirus genomes and the history of the outbreaks. This project will provide professional development opportunities for two early career scientists, and a public webinar for broader education and training on how to use the new software to study viral evolution will be hosted.<br/><br/>Novel analytical approaches for inferring the contemporary evolutionary history of SARS-CoV-2 strains will be developed. In preliminary investigations, the new procedures and protocols show higher power in resolving early evolutionary events in the SARS-CoV-2 history. New methods will be tested by using empirical and computer-simulated datasets. An extensive collection of coronavirus strains will be analyzed to reconstruct the earliest evolutionary events in its origin and divergence. The new software implementing the new methods will be integrated into the Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software that is used extensively in virology. This will place sophisticated techniques at the fingertips of scientists via a graphical user interface and command-line versions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Temple University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

POR.DRECONTENT:
Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is the root cause of the COVID-19 disease that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. Experimental laboratories have quickly assembled millions of CoV-2 genomes to characterize its variation and track the spread of COVID-19. This one-year project was primarily focused on advancing computational methods to infer evolutionary relationships of SARS-CoV-2 genomes and the early mutational history of COVID-19. These evolutionary patterns are important for making predictions and developing products to fight COVID-19.  In this project, we made the following advances:

(1) We developed a new approach to building the phylogeny of SARS-CoV-2 by adopting and advancing existing methods routinely used to infer the mutational history of tumor cells in a patient.

(2) We analyzed more than 68,000 SARS-CoV-2 genomes from the early phases of COVID-19 and produced reliable phylongey of SARS-CoV-2, overcoming challenge encountered by traditional phylogenetic methods.

(3) We reconstructed the genetic signature of the progenitor genome (proCoV2) that gave rise to all the infections in the world. Independent authors of a Wikipedia entry on SARS-CoV-2 variants listed our proCoV2 sequence as a primary progenitor sequence.

(4) We found that this progenitor likely existed months prior to the earliest reported outbreak in Wuhan, China. Our publication reporting these results has been covered extensively in public and the international media (AltMetric = 428).

(5) We reported that the progenitor mutated to produce many dominant coronavirus variants that spread episodically over time. Fingerprinting based on common variants revealed that the same coronavirus lineage dominated North America for most of the pandemic in 2020. We also found that there have been multiple replacements of predominant coronavirus strains in Europe and Asia and the continued presence of numerous high-frequency strains in Asia and North America.

(6) We participated in research project that found that the reinfection by SARS-CoV-2 under endemic conditions would likely occur in 16 months (median). This protection is less than half the duration revealed for the endemic coronaviruses circulating among humans.

(7) We released software for analysis and a dashboard of global evolution and spatiotemporal trends of SARS-CoV-2 (http://sars2evo.datamonkey.org/).


Last Modified: 10/18/2021
Modified by: Sudhir Kumar

Image
  • The progenitor coronavirus and its initial offspring, as inferred in ananalysis of more than 68,0000 SARS-CoV-2 genomes. Greek mutation symbols and evolutionary history are from Kumar et al. (Molec. Biol. Evol. [2021] 38:3046ï¿½3059). Common names of some variants are shown.
    Sudhir Kumar and Sayaka Miura
    Public Domain
    Sudhir Kumar
    The Mutational Phylogeny of SARS-CoV-2
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is the root cause of the COVID-19 disease that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. Experimental laboratories have quickly assembled millions of CoV-2 genomes to characterize its variation and track the spread of COVID-19. This one-year project was primarily focused on advancing computational methods to infer evolutionary relationships of SARS-CoV-2 genomes and the early mutational history of COVID-19. These evolutionary patterns are important for making predictions and developing products to fight COVID-19. In this project, we made the following advances: (1) We developed a new approach to building the phylogeny of SARS-CoV-2 by adopting and advancing existing methods routinely used to infer the mutational history of tumor cells in a patient. (2) We analyzed more than 68,000 SARS-CoV-2 genomes from the early phases of COVID-19 and produced reliable phylongey of SARS-CoV-2, overcoming challenge encountered by traditional phylogenetic methods. (3) We reconstructed the genetic signature of the progenitor genome (proCoV2) that gave rise to all the infections in the world. Independent authors of a Wikipedia entry on SARS-CoV-2 variants listed our proCoV2 sequence as a primary progenitor sequence. (4) We found that this progenitor likely existed months prior to the earliest reported outbreak in Wuhan, China. Our publication reporting these results has been covered extensively in public and the international media (AltMetric = 428). (5) We reported that the progenitor mutated to produce many dominant coronavirus variants that spread episodically over time. Fingerprinting based on common variants revealed that the same coronavirus lineage dominated North America for most of the pandemic in 2020. We also found that there have been multiple replacements of predominant coronavirus strains in Europe and Asia and the continued presence of numerous high-frequency strains in Asia and North America. (6) We participated in research project that found that the reinfection by SARS-CoV-2 under endemic conditions would likely occur in 16 months (median). This protection is less than half the duration revealed for the endemic coronaviruses circulating among humans. (7) We released software for analysis and a dashboard of global evolution and spatiotemporal trends of SARS-CoV-2 (http://sars2evo.datamonkey.org/).
